_link.title: I can explain why radioactive decay is described as random

toLevel2.question: What does it mean for radioactive decay to be random?
toLevel2.correct: We cannot predict when a specific nucleus will decay
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Radioactive decay is random because each individual nucleus has an equal probability of decaying at any moment, with no way to predict exactly when.

distractors.answer: All nuclei decay at the same time
distractors.explanation: If all nuclei decayed simultaneously, decay wouldn't be random; instead, decay occurs unpredictably over time.

distractors.answer: Decay only happens when triggered externally
distractors.explanation: Radioactive decay occurs spontaneously without external triggers, which is part of its random nature.

distractors.answer: Scientists have no understanding of decay
distractors.explanation: Scientists understand the statistics of decay very well; they just cannot predict individual events.

toLevel2.question: Why can scientists predict the decay rate of a large sample despite decay being random?
toLevel2.correct: Statistics become reliable with large numbers
toLevel2.correctExplanation: With billions of nuclei, statistical patterns emerge that allow accurate prediction of how many will decay in a given time.

distractors.answer: Large samples decay in a regular pattern
distractors.explanation: Individual decays are still random; statistics just become more predictable with large numbers.

distractors.answer: Scientists can control when each atom decays
distractors.explanation: Decay cannot be controlled; it occurs spontaneously and randomly.

distractors.answer: Each nucleus signals when it will decay
distractors.explanation: There is no signal or warning before decay; it happens spontaneously.

toLevel2.question: What is the term used to describe the time for half of a radioactive sample to decay?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Half-life is the time required for half of the nuclei in a sample to undergo radioactive decay.

distractors.answer: Decay constant
distractors.explanation: Decay constant is a different measure; half-life specifically refers to the time for half to decay.

distractors.answer: Full-life
distractors.explanation: There is no such term; half-life is the standard measure.

distractors.answer: Decay period
distractors.explanation: Half-life is the correct term for this specific measurement.

toLevel2.correctExplanation: Each unstable nucleus has the same probability of decaying at any instant, regardless of how long it has existed.

distractors.answer: Higher probability as the nucleus ages
distractors.explanation: A nucleus doesn't 'age'; its probability of decay stays constant over time.

distractors.answer: Lower probability during the first half-life
distractors.explanation: The probability is constant; it doesn't change during different periods.

distractors.answer: Zero probability until half-life is reached
distractors.explanation: Decay can occur at any time, not just after the half-life.

toLevel2.correctExplanation: Radioactive nuclei decay on their own without needing any external energy or trigger.

distractors.explanation: Temperature doesn't significantly affect radioactive decay rates.

distractors.answer: It requires a chemical reaction to begin

distractors.answer: It must be initiated by radiation exposure
distractors.explanation: Decay occurs naturally without requiring external radiation.

distractors.answer: False
distractors.explanation: Students may think that if we know enough about a nucleus, we could predict its decay, but quantum mechanics makes this fundamentally impossible.

distractors.answer: True
distractors.explanation: Students may think older nuclei are more likely to decay, but the probability is always constant.
